# Draft:Centre for Bioengineering, Queen Mary University of London

----
Overview
The Centre for Bioengineering is a multidisciplinary research and education hub within the School of Engineering and Materials Science at Queen Mary University of London. With roots in an EPSRC-funded Interdisciplinary Research Centre in Biomedical Materials, the Centre is dedicated to “Engineering Better Medicine”, focusing on cutting-edge biomedical engineering solutions. It encourages collaboration between academic researchers and external industry partners to drive innovation in bioengineering. The Centre builds upon Queen Mary's legacy in bioengineering and biomaterials, tracing back to foundational research activities supported by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC).
Leadership and People
The Centre is led by Professor Zion Tse, a Royal Society Wolfson Fellow and Academy of Medical Sciences Professor, serving as Head of the Centre. Additional leadership roles include:
* Professor [https://www.seresearch.qmul.ac.uk/bioengineering/people/khing/ Karin Hing] – Education Lead
* Professor [https://www.seresearch.qmul.ac.uk/bioengineering/people/tiskratsch/ Thomas Iskratsch] – Industry Lead
* Dr [https://www.seresearch.qmul.ac.uk/bioengineering/people/croney/ Caroline Roney] – Research Lead
The Centre’s broader academic team spans diverse expertise areas such as tissue engineering, mechanobiology, bioelectronics, regenerative medicine, computational medicine, robotics, and biointerfaces.
Research Themes & Facilities
Key research areas include:
* Organ-on-a-chip systems
* AI-driven cardiac modelling
* Biomaterials and biointerfaces
* Mechanobiology and tissue regeneration
* Computational models and digital twin technologies
* Robotics, mechatronics, and bioelectronics in medical applications
Facilities support advanced imaging and modelling techniques, high-fidelity mechanobiological testing, and translational tools such as organ-on-chip platforms.
Centres for Doctoral Training (CDT):
* EPSRC Centre for Doctoral Training in Organ-on-a-Chip technologies (COaCT)
Education & Impact
The Centre contributes to broader educational objectives through postgraduate and undergraduate programmes, integrating modern bioengineering methodologies into student training. Queen Mary students benefit from the Centre’s facilities, including mechanobiology labs and the Organs-on-Chips Centre.
Events & News
The Centre organises and participates in scientific events such as the UK Organ-on-a-Chip Symposium and the BioMedEng24 Conference.
Recent news includes:
* Hosting global research discussions like EnFI2025
* Securing MRC funding for developing human tendon-on-a-chip technologies
* Winning a £1.2 million British Heart Foundation programme grant
Contact and Location
Located within the School of Engineering and Materials Science, Mile End Road, London E1 4NS, United Kingdom
